keyTakeAways: Colonel Michael Randrianirina, a military officer, led a coup that overthrew former President Andry Rajoelina amid nationwide protests.
The new prime minister, Herintsalama Rajaonarivelo, was appointed due to his business background and international organizational connections.
The Gen Z Madagascar youth movement initiated protests over water and power cuts, which escalated into broader demands for systemic reform.
Former President Andry Rajoelina denies responsibility for a resignation letter and claims he is safe abroad, criticizing the coup as illegitimate.
International bodies, including the United Nations and African Union, have condemned the military takeover and suspended Madagascar’s membership.
The High Constitutional Court ratified the coup within hours of its occurrence, lending legal legitimacy to the new regime in domestic courts.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In October 2025, Madagascar experienced a political crisis following nationwide protests led by the Gen Z Madagascar youth movement, which began in September over water and power shortages. The protests escalated into demands for systemic reform, leading to the overthrow of former President Andry Rajoelina, who fled abroad and rejected responsibility for a forged resignation letter. In response, Colonel Michael Randrianirina, a long-time critic of Rajoelina, led a military coup, taking power and being sworn in as president. He appointed businessman Herintsalama Rajaonarivelo as prime minister, citing his international connections and experience. The move was immediately condemned by the United Nations and the African Union, which suspended Madagascar’s membership. Domestically, the High Constitutional Court ratified the coup within hours, lending legal legitimacy to the new government.
